summary: An assailant injured an man with a machete inside a supermarket in Mold, Flintshire, on 14 January. Lee Rigby was a soldier who was murdered by Islamist extremists in Woolwich, London, in 2014.

summary: A man attacked a police station in Joue les Tours and wounded three police officers on 20 December. He was killed by another police officer thereafter. Another two police officers who tried to overpower him suffered a stab wound and minor cut. Police were still investigating the motive of the attacker at time of writing, though it has been reported that the man was suffering from depression and converted to Islam four months ago.

summary:
Seven TTP militants, armed with guns and wearing explosive vests, killed 141 people, including 132 children, in the deadliest attack in Pakistan on 16 December.
The militants entered the Army Public School in Peshawar through the back wall of the compound. They attacked the school's main hall then went classroom to classroom shooting children and teachers. The militants then detonated their devices when the military arrived.
The TTP claimed responsibility for the massacre, not its splinter faction Jamaat-ul-Ahrar (JA) as was initially reported in several Pakistani media outlets. In a message in English and Urdu released today, the TTP said that the attack was in retaliation for the ongoing military operations in North Waziristan and extra-judicial killings by Pakistani soldiers. The group warned that it would ‘be forced to attack all the organisations associated with the security forces of Pakistan' if the military continued to commit ‘further genocide' of tribal people.
area: Army Public School, Peshawar, Khyber Pakhytunkhwa
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
In the first terrorist attack in Australia in over 20 years, a gunman entered a cafe in downtown Sydney and took customers and staff hostage in a 16 hour-long standoff on 15 December.
Australian media outlets reported that the gunman - Man Haron Monis, a 49-year old Iranian asylum seeker - entered the Lindt cafe in Martin Place in the Central Business District of Sydney at about 0940hrs and after sitting down at a table for a few minutes pulled out a small gun and ordered staff to lock the doors. The gunman held 17 people hostage.
While the gunman was distracted talking to other hostages, five people fled the cafe through a fire escape about five hours into the attack. Another five hostages escaped around 0220hrs on 16 December, as security forces stormed the building.
Commandos stormed the cafe through a back door at around 0200hrs after hearing shots fired in the cafe, according to media reports. Security forces killed the attacker and the authorities confirmed that two people died in the attack and four others, including a police officer, were injured. An investigation is ongoing as to whether the gunman killed the victims or if they died in the crossfire.
area: Cafe Lindt, Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jihadist (undetermined), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: True,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: Multiple assailants hacked a university professor to death outside his home in Rajshahi, Rajshahi district, Rajshahi division at around 1500hrs on 15 November. summary:
Two car bombs exploded in Tripoli outside the Egyptian and the UAE embassies early in the morning on 13 November. The bombings did not cause any injuries according to security officials. Both Egypt and the UAE closed their embassies months ago due to increased violence in the city. According to media reports, the bombs caused significant damage to both buildings and the houses surrounding the Egyptian embassy. No individual or group claimed responsibility for the attacks at the time of writing.
Egypt and the UAE have provided support to the internationality-recognized government based in Tobruk, which has been vying for power with a second rival government, established in Tripoli. The blasts occurred a day after twin bombs exploded in Toburk and Labraq on 12 November.

summary:
A Canadian man drove his car into two soldiers in the parking lot of a supermarket in Saint Jean sur Richelieu, Quebec at approximately 1130hrs on 20 October, killing one of the soldiers and injuring the other. The assailant then called the national emergency line to claim the attack. He then fled the scene pursued by the police, before crashing his car into a ditch. Police then shot the assailant after he emerged from car with a knife. Canadian media reports suggested that the assailant waited in his car for over two hours before attacking the officers.
Authorities identified the assailant as 25-year-old Marin Couture-Rouleau. Officials reported that they monitored Couture-Rouleau along with 90 other Canadians deemed potential terrorist threats. Authorities previously detained Couture-Rouleau at the airport after he attempted to board a plane to Turkey earlier in the year. Police questioned him for links to a group affiliated with Islamic State but found no conclusive evidence.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jihadist (undetermined), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Police officials announced they had arrested thirteen members of a militant group on 18 October. According to police sources, the group was planning to launch attacks on an army unit and seize weapons, as well as detonate bombs in two major tunnels linking the north with the rest of the country. It can be assumed that the tunnels were Anzob and Shahriston tunnels, as they are on the major M34 road.
The arrested individuals are allegedly members of Jundullah, which has links to the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan IMU). The announcement of the arrest was made few months ahead of the parliamentary elections in February 2015. Similar announcements of foiled terrorist plots happened in the leadup to the presidential elections in 2013.

summary:
Islamic State militants released a video on 3 October purportedly showing the beheading of a British aid worker. According to international media reports, Islamic State militants kidnapped the aid worker in December 2013. The group threatened to kill Henning in a video released in September, which showed the murder of another British aid worker David Haines.
The group claimed they killed Henning in revenge for the UK's participation in US-led military action in Iraq and Syria. At the end of the video, the group threatened to kill an American named Abdul Rahman Kassig, should the air strikes continue. This was the fourth video issued by the group depicting the beheading of a Westerner. The exact location of each of the beheadings is not known, although international media reports speculate that it is near Raqqa.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

A suicide bomber then detonated his device as first responders arrived. Reports differ over whether the bomber was on foot or in a vehicle. specific_target: Anti-terror police officer SSP Farooq Awan
summary:
A bomb exploded in Karachi near the Gizri graveyard on Khayaban-e-Momin roadat 2104hrson 25 September. The attack targeted a senior anti-terror police officer SSP Farooq Awan. The explosion killed two people and seven others were injured including SSP Awan. This is the third attack targeting SSP Awan.
CCTV footage showed a vehicle parked at the site of the explosion near the Saudi consulate. Police officials reported that up to 100kg of explosives were used in the attack and the blast was heard in many nearby areas of Karachi including Clifton and Defence. According to police, militants used a remote controlled device to trigger the explosion.
Some local media outlets reported that the attack Jundullah claimed the attack however at the time of writing this was not confirmed.
source_urls: Express Tribune; http://tribune.com.pk/story/767192/loud-explosion-heard-in-karachis-defence-area/ ; Dawn News; http://www.dawn.com/news/1134294/bomb-attack-on-police-officer-kills-two-injures-six-in-karachi ; The News; http://www.thenews.com.pk/Todays-News-13-33128-Two-killed-as-Karachi-SSP-survives-car-bomb-attack

Soldiers of the Caliphate (SOC or Jund Al-Khilafa) kidnapped a French national on 21 September in the mountainous Kabylie region in northeast Algeria. According to a message issued on jihadist forums and Twitter that same day, the group said they carried out the kidnapping in ‘compliance with the command of' IS spokesman Abu Mohamed Adnani.
This claim appears to be in reference to Adnani's order issued on 21 September as the kidnapping to attack Westerners in retaliation for military operations against IS in Iraq and Syria. SOC has threatened to kill the victim within 24 hours if France continues to support the US-led mission.
On 24 September, the group beheaded the French national and posted a video of the murder online.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Jund al-Khilafah, perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
Taliban militants attacked a government compound in Ghazni province on 4 September. The building houses the regional intelligence agency. About 20 insurgents first attacked the compound by detonating a truck bomb outside its gates. They then mounted an assault using machine guns and grenade launchers in a battle that lasted nearly three hours. Officials said that security forces killed 19 militants.
International and local media reports vary over the number of security personnel killed. Some reports said that 13 officers died in the attack while others put the figure at 18 people. Media reports also indicated that the attack injured over 150 people. The Taliban subsequently claimed responsibility for the attack on its website.

summary:
The Islamic State released a video on 2 September showing the beheading of US journalist Steven Sotloff by one of their members. The group had threatened to execute Sotloff in a video released exactly two weeks earlier of the beheading of James Folley, another US journalist, should US airstrikes continue in Iraq.
US and British authorities said the video was authentic and the militant featured in the video was most probably a British national. At the time of writing, Western governments and the Islamic State have not identified or revealed where the murders took place. However, several international media reports indicate that the killing likely occurred in or near Raqqa, Syria, where IS has a strong presence.

summary:
The Islamic State released a video on 19 August showing an unidentifiedmilitant purportedly beheading James Foley, an American journalist, whom militants had kidnapped in Syria in 2012.
The video concluded with the militant threatening that another hostage, Steven Sotloff, an American journalist kidnapped in 2013, would be killed if the US did not halt its bombing campaign against the Islamic State. The group did not disclose exact time and the location of the beheading, nor have Western governments provided further details. However, several security sources quoted in international media reports indicate that it is likely that the murder took place near Raqqa, Syria, where the Islamic State has a substantial presence.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Islamic State (IS), perpetrator_type: Global Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
The Sixth Division of the National Army neutralised a 12 cylinder bomb found on the road betweenFlorencia and San Vicente del Caguan. The cylinders, each with a 40-pound capacity were found along with shrapnel compounds, electric detonators and a detonating cord. The cylinders were located at 7 metre intervals and had a destructive capacity of approxiamtely 200m. If detonated, it would have left the populaiton of northern Chaqueta without communication.
According to the army, cited by local press,guerrillas from theTeófilo Forero group from the southern organisation of FARC were responsible. The army also claims the attack was to target a patrol of the armed forces. The army blocked off the area and detonated the cylinders in a controlled environment. No individual or group has claimed responsibility for the attack.

summary:
An Al-Shabaab suicide bomber killed a police commander, driver and two of his bodyguards at a police station in Bossasso. Security officials, quoted in Somali media reports, said that the Bari region police commander was the intended target.

The group said ‘with the blessings of Allah, the Mujahideen have carried out a successful operation targeting senior apostate officials in the Bari region of Somalia. summary: Around 0400hrs, suicide bombers and gunmen attacked a bus transferring inmates from a prison in Taji, north of Baghdad, killing 51 prisoners and nine policemen dead on 24 July. The attack reportedly involved a combination of suicide bombers, IEDs and shooters, and occurred hours before UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon's planned talks with Iraqi PM Nouri Al-Maliki. No group has claimed responsibility for the attack at the time of publication.

summary:
Unidentified militants bombed a church, the Iglesia de Santa Ana in Santiago, at around 0400hrs on 22 July. There were no reports of casualties and no group claimed responsibility for the attack at the time of publication.
A phamplet found at the scene read 'our insurrectional action is a gesture of solidarity with our comrades Fransisco Solar and Monica Caballero, detained in Spain'. Fransisco Solar and Monica Caballero were Chilean anarchists jailed Spain for their part in the bombing of the Basilica of Pilar de Zaragoza on 2 October 2013 .
The attack took place on the same day unidentified militants planted a bomb near a children's nursery and two weeks after a bomb exploded on the metro in Santiago. The authorities did not comment at the time of writing if the incidents were connected.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
FARC militants bomb two electricity towers in Putumayo, as part of a recent campaign of sabotage in the area. The attack resulted in the loss of power to three municipalities, affecting about 100,000 people living in the area.

The group has claimed that its actions were partially in response to a government campaign of arial fumigation of local crops, which ostensibly targeted cocaine production.

summary: Unidentified militants attacked an oil company’s facility on Sunday 29 June 2014, in the city of Arauca, closed to the Colombia-Venezuela border. This attack is linked to three other attacks on the Caño Limón-Coveñasoil pipe line in the localities of Tarra in 19 June, Tame in 24 June and Teorama in 28 June, in north eastern Colombia. summary:
At around 2230hrs, gunmen fired at a Pakistan International Airlines flight landing in Peshawar, killing a passenger and wounding two crew members.
Police have indicated that they believe gunmen intentionally targeted the plane, but no-one has claimed responsibility at the time of publication. The Civil Aviation Authority suspended all services to and from the airport following the incident.
The incident happened as flight PK756 carrying 190 passengers and crew descended to about 90m and was approaching Bacha Khan International Airport from the south. According to security officials, six bullets from an automatic rifle hit the Airbus A310 from Riyadh. It is unclear where the gunmen fired from during the attack, and it is possible that the assailants might be based either in Peshawar or the nearby tribal areas.
area: Peshawar,  Bacha Khan Airport, Federally Administered Tribal Area

specific_target: General Security director Maj. Gen. Abbas Ibrahim
summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a Internal Security Forces checkpoint in Dahr al Baydar at 1130hrs on 20 June. The attack took place as the director of general security, Major General Abbas Ibrahim was driving through the checkpoint. The general was unharmed, however an ISF officer and a civilian died. The explosion also wounded 18 others, including six ISF officer. No group claimed responsibility at the time of publication.
The checkpoint is located on the highway between Beirut and Damascus. According to local media reports, the suicide bomber traveled from Beirut. Security forces closed the highway in both directions in response to the incident.

summary:
Attackers driving two off-road vehicles ploughed into people at a busy open-air street market near Renmin Park, central Urumqi, Xinjiang on 22 May. Witness quoted in Chinese state media said the attackers also threw explosive devices from the cars. The assault was the deadliest in China for years and appears to be the latest in a series of high profile attacks perpetrated by Uighur extremists in the past seven months.
According to state media, at least 31 people died and more than 90 others were injured during the attack that saw at least 12 explosions, including one of the vehicles. The incident took place during the busy morning shopping period at a market reportedly run and patronised mainly by ethnic Han Chinese.
No group claimed responsiblity for the attack at the time of publication.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
A bomb exploded when Colonel Talal al-Urduni, the commander of the Shatila Martyrs Brigade, drove past a scrap shop in the al-Kinayat neighbourhood of the Ain al-Hilweh refugee camp near Sidon, Lebanon on the afternoon of 19 May.
The explosion did not cause any fatalities but it wounded three of al-Urduni's companions and Colonel Abu Shadi al-Sabarbari, who was travelling with al-Urduni. The attack also damaged al-Urduni's car, a cafe nearby, surrounding shops and several homes. When the explosion occured, al-Urduni was returning from a meeting at the Palestinian embassy in Beirut and returning to his office and home in the camp's Hittin neighbourhood, via the Darb al-Sim checkpoint.
According to security sources quoted in the Lebanese media, the device was composed of two kilograms of explosive material filled and small metallic balls and was detonated by a mobile phone. Eyewitnesses reported that prior to the explosion a young boy placed an object in a scrap pile and then left the site.
source_urls: Al Akhbar English - http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/al-qaeda-plays-explosives-ain-al-hilweh?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+AlAkhbarEnglish+(Al+Akhbar+English); The Daily Star - http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Lebanon-News/2014/May-20/257076-assassination-attempt-adds-to-ain-al-hilweh-woes.ashx#axzz329N7eB51

summary:
Al Shabab militants attacked a Mandera County security team 5km from Mandera as it was driving to El Wak, which is near the border between Kenya and Somalia.
Al Shabab spokesman Abdulaziz Abu Musab claimed that the group had killed all of the Kenyan soldiers and five police officers, in addition to stealing two pickup trucks and taking them across the border. However, Kenyan military spokesman Major Emmanuel Chirchir and local police chief Noah Mwivanda both said that there were no casualties from the attack.
These officials announced that the Kenyan officers responded to the attack and the militants fled towards Somalia. At the time of the attack, the security team was travelling to El Wak in order to reconcile fighting between the Degodia and Gare clans.

summary:
Around 0015hrs on 18 May, two homemade bottle bombs filled with acid and metal shards exploded in the AMC Tysons Corner 16 movie theatre in McLean, Virginia during a midnight showing of 'Godzilla'. More than 2,000 people evacuated the vicinity, and no one was injured.
According to fire officials, they believe the bombs were two-litre plastic soda bottles. On 5 April 2014 another bottle bomb exploded outside a movie theatre in Alexandria, Virginia, which is approximately 30km away from McLean. However, Fire Department spokesman Dan Schmidt said that authorities did not know if the incidents were related.

summary:
A car bomb and a suicide bomber caused eleven deaths and 33 injured in downtown Iraq on 15 May . A car bomb exploded in a parking lot in the Karrada neighbourhood, a busy commercial district where some government offices are also located. The second explosion came a few minutes later when a suicide bomber detonated his explosive belt at the main gate of an office affiliated with the higher education ministry. The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant claimed responsibility for the attacks.
The attacks take place only two days after a series of car bombings killed at least 34 people in the Iraqi capital.

summary:
Two children threw a grenade at a police station in Narino, southwest Colombia on 14 May. The attack injured eight police officers and resulted in the deaths of the two children.
Commander of the Narino Police, General Ramiro Mena, has attributed the attack to the Daniel Aldana column of the FARC. According to international media reports, the group has a strong presence in the area.
It is not the first time the FARC used children to perpetrated attacks. In 2010, a child delivered a parcel bomb in Elcharco, Narino which exploded as he carried it. The attack killed the child and wounded many others.
perpetrators: Colombia:Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC):Far Left/Revolutionary

summary:
The police and the Irish defence forces bomb disposal unit diffused a 22kg bomb planted in a car in the Finnstown Country House Hotel car park on 10 May 2014.
Police confirmed that the device was viable. The bomb was reportedly made of fertiliser in a metal keg and had a relatively sophisticated timed detonator. The Gardaí arrested Samuel Devlin, a man from Belfast suspected of being an Irish Republican Army member, in connection to the incident. On 13 May, Devlin appeared in front of the special criminal court in Dublin and was charged with membership of an unlawful organisation and unlawful possession of explosives.

summary:
Guerrillas, suspected by the authorities to be members of ELN, attacked a section of the Cano Limon-Covenas pipeline located in the Cubara region causing an oil spill. There were no reports of casualties, but the oil spill resulted in a significant public health emergency due to the proximity of rivers that supply water to nearby populations. Water consumption in the Agualinda region has been temporarily suspended.
The 770km-long pipeline supplies oil from the Northeastern region of Arauca to the Caribbean port of Covenas. The ELN and the FARC have perpetrated over 30 attacks to both the Cano Limon-Covenas and the Bicentenario pipelines over the first three months of 2014. The rebel groups have claimed that their purpose is to stop the exploitation of Colombia's natural resources by foreign countries.
The attack came a day after the U'wa indigenous tribes reached an agreement with the Colombian government to end their protests and allow technicians to repair another nearby section of that same pipeline that was damaged on 25 March.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: National Liberation Army (ELN), perpetrator_type: Far Left/Revolutionary,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

Upon entering the town, the Prime Minister's convoy was attacked again by al-Shabaab militants. The Prime Minister survived both attacks. Al-Shabaab claimed responsibility for both attacks, stating their aim was to assassinate the Prime Minister.

summary:
Unidentified militants detonated a bomb near the National Database and Registration Authority in Quetta on 8 May. The attack killed two people and wounded at least 15 others. The bomb also damaged the surrounding cars and motorcycles.
According to a senior police official and bomb disposal experts quoted in the Pakistani media, the bomb weighed more than 10kg and was concealed in a parked motorcycle. Although the intended target of the attack was unconfirmed, the Station House Officer at a local police station believes that a police van patrolling the area at the time of the explosion could have been the target. The bomb detonated as the police van passed by it.

specific_target: Gamboru-Ngala highway bridge connecting Nigeria and Cameroon
summary: Militants, suspected by the authorities of belonging to Boko Haram, detonated a bomb on the Gamboru-Ngala Road bridge that connects Nigeria to Cameroon on the afternoon of 8 May. The attack killed 30 people and left hundreds of trucks transporting commodities between the two countries stranded on either side of the bridge. The frames of the bridge were damaged but still standing, so small passenger cars could still cross the bridge. The bombing occured while local villagers were conducting a mass burial for the victims of the Boko Haram attack in Gamboru-Ngala on 5 May that killed 336 people.

summary:
Four unidentified attackers wounded six people in a knife attack in Guangzhou railway station on 6 May.The casualties include one Westerner, according to the South China Morning Post. This is the third knife attack by multiple assailants at a busy railway station in China in a little over nine weeks, following incidents in Kunming in early March and Urumqi on 30 April.
According to reports in the international media and the Communist Party People's Daily, four attackers dressed in white clothes and caps attacked crowds at the station in the southern city of Guangzhou. Similar to earlier cases the assailants reportedly tried to stab victims in the head or neck. Police shot and killed one of the attackers, but the other two apparently escaped the scene.
Although no group or individual claimed responibility for the attack, authorities believeXinjiang separatists were responsible.
area: Guangzhou railway station, Guangzhou, Guangdong Province

summary:
Boko Haram militants killed about 300 of people during a raid in the town of Gamboru Ngala, on the Nigerian-Cameroonian border, on the night of 6 May, according to international media reports. However, figures of the number of casualties vary with reliable media outlets mentioning figures between 300 - 500 people.
If these reports are correct, this would be the largest number of fatalities that we have recorded for an attack by Boko Haram since the group emerged in its current form in 2009. And it would probably be the largest single violent incident perpetrated by an African Islamist militant group since the 1997 Bentalha massacre by the Armed Islamic Group (GIA) in Algeria.
The gunmen also looted shops and homes, set fire to several buildings, including a police station, and 17 trailers loaded with livestocks. According to sources quoted in international media, the attack occurred after security forces deployed in the town were moved to another area as part of the operation to rescues the schoolgirls abducted in Chibok on April.

summary:
Two small bombs exploded in quick succession on a train at the busy Chennai Central railway station in Tamil Nadu state at approximately 0730hrs on 1 May.The Indian authorities have confirmed that one person died and 14 others were injured on the Bangalore-Guwahati Express.
Chennai police officials have said that low intensity blasts took place in two adjoining sleeper carriages. The explosives were reportedly hidden underneath passenger seats, and police suspect were triggered remotely by ‘a basic mobile device'. Pictures and video footage of the carriages also appear to show limited material damage to the bunks of the coaches.
No group has claimed responsibility for the attack at the time of publication.

summary: Four attackers threw petrol bombs an Alliance Party office in east Belfast on Upper Newtownards Road, Belfast on 29 April. The attack took place at around 2300hrs. No casualties were reported and no group claimed responsibility for the attack at the time of writing.
source_urls: BBC - Seven petrol bombs have been thrown at an Alliance Party office in east Belfast, the police have said.; The attack on the premises on the Upper Newtownards Road happened at about 23:00 BST on Tuesday.; Scorch damage was caused to the building and windows were smashed, but no-one was injured.; The police have recovered CCTV footage of the attack showing at least four people were involved.; The footage, which has been seen by the BBC, shows they were wearing hooded tops and began throwing stones and bricks at windows of the office just before 23:00 BST.; Once they had broken glass in an upstairs window, the attackers began hurling petrol bombs, before running off.; Naomi Long said the party 'will not be driven out' of east Belfast; The pictures also show seven petrol bombs being thrown.; The police are studying the footage but, at this stage, it is not being released to the media.; Chief Inspector Darren Jones said a number of witnesses had already come forward, but appealed for more.; The office has been targeted a number of times since a vote on the flying of the union flag at Belfast City Hall in December 2012.; East Belfast Alliance MP Naomi Long said the party would "not be driven out".; "There will be no no-go areas in east Belfast for the Alliance party or for anybody else while I'm elected in this constituency," she said.
area: Upper Newtownards Road, Belfast, Northern Ireland

summary:
A bomb explosion took place near a mosque in the Clifton neighbourhood of Karachi on 25 April. The attack killed four people, although the exact number of casualties is unknown. Pakistani media report that between 24 and 30 people were wounded in the attack.
Abdul Khaliq Sheikh, a senior police official quoted in Pakisani media, claimed that a motorcycle was used in the attack. However, it is unclear if it was a suicide attack or if the bomb was planted. The provincial information minister, Sharjeel Memon, suspected the bombers were attempting to target government vehicles passing through the area. No individual or group claimed responsibility for the attack at the time of publication.

summary:
A car bomb exploded outside a police station in the Pangani neighbourhood of Nairobi on the evening of 23 April. The attack killed two police officers and two militants. No group claimed the attack at the time of publication, but officials have blamed Al-Shabaab.
Images of the scene of the bombing and information from Kenyan journalists who visited the site suggested that the bomb was powerful. The car was completely destroyed with large pieces of shrapnel lying at least 20 metres from the blast site. Also, residents in the city quoted in local news reports said they could hear the explosion from several kilometres away.
The attack was the first successful bombing using a vehicle-borne device in Kenya in at least three and a half years. It follows the mass arrests of ethnic-Somalis by Kenyan police in recent weeks. The security operation has centred on the predominately-Somali Eastleigh neighbourhood.

summary:
Two unidentified gunmen driving a motorcycle killed a Yemeni intelligence officer on Airport Road in Sana'a, at around 1320hrs on 22 April.
The gunmen fled immediately after the attack. Although no group or individual claimed the assassination, Yemeni authorities suspect Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) militants were responsible for the attack.
Colonel Abdul Rakaz al-Jabali was the fourth officer to be killed in Sana'a in two days. These killings came two days after a US drone and air strike campaign that allegedly killed 68 AQAP members and affiliates.

summary:
An unspecified number of armed militants riding motorcycles opened fire on a convoy of seven NATO oil tankers en route to Afghanistan. The attack killed the driver of the last vehicle in the convoy but no other injuries were reported in the incident.

It is unclear whether these two developments are related as the perpetrators of the convoy attack have not been identified.

summary:

summary:
The Lebanese Army exchanged fire with unidentified gunmen in the neighbourhood of Bab al-Tabbaneh in Tripoli on 9 April. At around 2100hrs, an unspecified number of men threw granades at an army unit patroling the area. The military fired in response, beginning a gun fight that lasted several hours. The authorities reported that only one soldier was wounded.
According to sources quoted in the Lebanese press, the army arrested at least two men, identified as Houssam al Dayekh and Mahmoud Qassem. The attack followed a military operation that occurred earlier that same day. Authorities reported that in this operation, soldiers arrested several people linked to attacks in Tripoli.

The incident came two days prior to elections in the region, which were scheduled to take place on 10 April.

summary:
Four gunmen attacked the Serena Hotel in Kabul on 20 March. The gunmen killed nine people including four foreigners. The Taliban claimed responsibility for the attack.
According to international media, the gunmen were teenagers and managed to evade security provisions, such as metal detectors at the hotel's entrance, by hiding six small pistols and several rounds of ammunition in their shoes. The gunmen hid in the hotel's toilets for about three hours before opening fire on diners in the hotel's restaurant. Afghan security forces quickly arrived and killed the gunmen after a prolonged exchange of gunfire.

summary:
An improvised explosive device exploded around 1300hrs on 24 February outside an Anglican cathedral near Stone Town, the capital of Zanzibar. According to international media, the explosion occurred simultaneously with another attack on Mercury's restaurant on Mizingani Road, Stone Town. The attacks caused no casualties and resulted in only minor structural damage. No individual or group claimed either attack.
Terrorist attacks are a rare occurrence in Tanzania: Terrorism Tracker has recorded just two other incidents in the past year. These were relatively small-scale and unsophisticated bombings of churches on the mainland, in Dar es Salam and Arusha in August and May 2013 respectively. Radical Islamist groups and individuals in Tanzania have also assaulted several priests and tourists during the past year. These have tended to occur in the predominately Muslim coastal areas and on Zanzibar island.
area: Christ Church (Anglican) Cathedral, Mchambawima, Stone Town, Zanzibar
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Unknown, perpetrator_type: Undetermined,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
At approximately 1745hrs on 24 February, a suicide bomb attack at a checkpoint near the Iranian Consulate on Park Avenue in Peshawar killed at least two paramilitary Frontier Corps guards and injured 11 others.
The state security measures in the area were successful in preventing the bomber from reaching the consulate building. According to police accounts, a suicide bomber drove up to the checkpoint and detonated the explosives as he stepped out of the vehicle after security forces present at the checkpoint had warned him. The head of the Peshawar police said that the target may have been ‘either the Iranian Consulate or another nearby office'. In addition to the consulate, there are several NGO offices and schools in the University Town area, as well as UN offices, the ICRC, and the American Club.
A spokesman for a group led by militant Mast Gul, affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban (TTP), claimed the attack to Reuters and said the consulate was the intended target. The spokesman warned that the group would ‘continue to target Iranian installations and the Shia community everywhere'.
According to Pakistani media outlets, security forces subsequently cordoned off the area and increased the police presence at the site.
area: Iran Consulate, Park Avenue, Peshawar, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan (TTP), perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: True, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary: Four suicide bombers attacked Gereshk District headquarters in Afghanistan's Helmand province on 6 February. One suicide bomber detonated his device at 1130hrs at the gate so three more could enter. A two hour gun battle ensued between the remaining suicide bombers and the police. summary:
A sucide bomber driving a car attacked a restaurant close to a checkpoint one street away from the Green Zone. The attack killed at least eight people.
According to international media, four more bombs exploded at Khulani Square in the city's commercial centre, outside the Iraqi foreign ministry and in southeastern Baghdad. Police officials quoted in international media said at least 33 were killed and 123 wounded in total in attacks in Baghad on 5 February.

summary: At least one suicide car bomb exploded in a parking lot outside the Iraqi foreign ministry killing at least 11 people. Reports differ in Iraqi and international media over the exact number of car bombs that exploded outside the foreign ministry. According to Reuters, security sources told their reporters that there were two suicide car bombs exploded in the parking lot. However, CNN and AFP report that there was only one bomber.  According to international media, four more bombs exploded at a nearby restaurant as well as in the city's commercial centre and in southeastern Baghdad. Police officials quoted in international media said at least 33 were killed and 123 wounded in total in attacks in Baghad on 5 February.

summary:
A suicide bomber attacked a Lebanese restaurant in the diplomatic quarter of central Kabul. According to a Kabul police spokesperson, the attack took place just after dark on 17 January as the bomber detonated his explosive vest just at the restaurant's entrance. Two other gunmen entered the restaurant and subsequently opened fire. The Taliban claimed responsiblity for the attack.
The explosion killed 21 people, including two British citizens, two Americans, the head of the International Monetary Fund's Afghanistan office, two Canadians, the restaurant's Lebanese owner and another Lebanese citizen, a Danish citizen, a Russian citizen, a Malaysian and a Pakistani. The attack left eight Afghans dead. It is unclear how many people were injured in the bombing.
Taliban spokesperson, Zabihullah Mujahid said in an emailed statement 'the target of the attack was a restaurant frequented by high-ranking foreigners...where the invaders used to dine with booze and liquor in the plenty'.
author: Unknown author
attributions: perpetrator_name: Taliban, perpetrator_type: National Islamist,is_claimed: False, is_suspected: False,is_officially_attributed: False

summary:
